author: bridge-bot
content: <vdWijden> During initial sync, we request up to 8k blocks (depending on how big the last ones were), so a bunch of empty followed by a bunch of big blocks will make us keep a lot of big blocks in ram

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not talking about archive nodes, just regular RPC fulfilling nodes which require full state (stateless doesn't help them).  You are correct that we have been ignoring this problem for a very long time with no clear roadmap to fix it and it has been getting progressively worse over time.

author: bridge-bot
content:

> <sky.cactus> [reply]: I'm not talking about archive nodes, just regular RPC fulfilling nodes which require full state (stateless doesn't help them).  You are correct that we have been ignoring this problem for a very long time with no clear roadmap to fix it and it has been getting progressively worse over time.
I think helius solved this a long time ago. Rely on eth_getProof and rely on a CL lightclient as a source of truth. But anyway, data access cost increases logarithmically so it unlikely it will have a significant performance impact (esp. read-only actions). It should grow similarly to block importing

author: sky.cactus
content: It is not solved in the real world. Proofs are too expensive, there is no incentive for running a server, if you send full call you lose privacy, and if you only request state as needed response time is horrible due to many round trips per request (and you still lose some privacy).
